33y_Qz-WX0rn1OsNzMbzPQ.text: Pitstop food rather than than destination for a special meal. It does this well serving up crowd-pleaser food swiftly. The place has a comtemporary feel, looks clean but all the hard surfaces means it is a bit noisy. It is busy so they are doing something right. Very well placed just by Leicester Square tube station.

B0M2YJ7XzXd3kOLgUJIr9A.text: Excellent food. Calamari was worth waiting for.  One of the best. Great value for what you get. Loved it!

VoIZ2dB--DIj4oA1O9z7ZQ.text: Had my doubts when I saw the trendy main dining room, but simple, exceptional pizza and pasta and friendly staff won out.  Not big on ambience (go downstairs!), but that's almost part of the charm!

ZzMP7TmafggghpLctZAkDA.text: Sartori never disappoints! Although it doesn't look like much from the outside, the food is delicious! The pizzas are great, with a nice doughy crust, and can be ordered by the meter which is a lot of fun for large groups! The pasta was just as lovely.The service is good, but speediness could be improved slightly however.

pz0115qCRYaUR8kr1ylsSg.text: Sartori is a superb new Italian joint, opened October 2010, in the heart of the theatre district in London's West End. I love pizza. By that, I mean I hate Pizza Sexpress, can't stand Deep Bland Pizza, abhor Pizza Slut, can't be arsed with Ask, and please don't get me started on how Dodgy Domino's has single-handedly bastardised the concept of pizza and turned it into the Divine Brown of the UK Pizza scene. ("You're hungry, you say? And you have no soul? Here, use my Domino's Calling Card! You can find them in most phone booths around town! It will feel great at the time and they will deliver straight to your door!") Truth is, Brits just don't get pizza. The idea that there exists this unspoken hierarchy of quality that differentiates Ask from Pizza Express from Pizza Hut is absolutely bonkers. Fact is they are all lowest-common-denominator, hen-do-serving chain restaurants whose sole purpose is to shovel out food that is marginally above adequate according to the British palate (and we all know what that means), thus making the most profit possible. It's how Tesco and Starbucks operate, and the discerning foodie should shun them not because they are all corporate and evil like, but because they have forgotten what it means to do things that make you smile. Sartori, this lovely cosy and sophisticated little restaurant in central London, is the perfect antidote to the above. If I tell you that this restaurant transported their pizza oven piece-by-piece directly from Naples and reconstructed it in their basement (no expense spared: the whole thing cost a cool £18k), you might correctly assume that they also shipped-in chefs from Naples to operate the beast as well. And if you know a thing or two about the average food ethic of a chef in Naples, and the commitment they have to the art of making pizza, you might start to understand that you are in for a rare treat. Actually I first heard about this place when I was looking at reviews of my favourite new coffee house nearby, Notes Music and Coffee, who have probably the most expensive and sought-after espresso machine currently in the world. Sartori was noted in the same piece as having the Maserati of pizza ovens. I had to investigate. I had to see it for myself. A quick look downstairs at this oven, and a chat with a waiter, confirms this is indeed the Maserati of pizza ovens. The waiter actually compared it to a Ferrari, but the point is that this restaurant is sufficiently geeky about the construction of a pizza to employ pizzaioli who know exactly what they are doing. Their menu proudly states "please refrain from asking for a variation of toppings; our pizzaioli are experienced in the art of combining ingredients"... and my Pizza Napoletana was the evidence. Each new mouthful tasted different to the last, each made me go 'wow', and without wishing to gush too much, each mouthful made me further resolve to tell all my friends about this place. If pizza isn't your thing, there are numerous other dishes from Naples to get excited about. Although the aspirations are high, this is a humble restaurant. The service is smart and friendly, the decor is classy, the atmosphere is intimate, and the prices are astonishingly low given its location. When you visit, you absolutely must go downstairs and take a look at the oven. The chefs might stare at you like you are a bit strange, but it's a thing of beauty. It has an integrated area for storage of wood. What's not to love? A great place for a date or a meal with good friends, and it won't break the bank. If you fancy a coffee pilgrimage at the same time, visit Notes Music and Coffee just down the road (open late).

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

LO8eyWVpfsVrySA0bsC6lA.text: Not the usual Italian scam, but an actual Italian restaurant run by Italians that serves good pizza (the meter option is great to try different toppings and fun to share) for an honest prize. I feel at home!!

sdp4-veNZokFcg56kVrplQ.text: One of the best Italian restaurants I've  been to,amazing food, amazing service and great location!must try!

z4Ba2LOoFmI7Levfo8OQNw.text: Excellent pizza and lovely tuna. Great food, fun but very noisy place. Fairly expensive but this is London.

rxRU5cuA1e_HO25Uwtj7-w.text: This is one of my favourite London restaurants; I must have been here about a dozen times! The food is about as authentic as it gets outside of Italy (for example, they use pecorino in some dishes, instead of the default parmesan you see everywhere). I have taken many friends here, and everyone has loved it (including the Italians!). I always have a lot of trouble deciding what to order, because I know it's all so delicious. As almost everyone else has mentioned, the pizzas are definitely worth trying, but the pasta is good too. Just note that the main course portions are pretty huge!Regarding the service, I haven't had any particular issues (once the waiter misunderstood my pizza order, and they made the wrong one, but made me a fresh pizza within about five minutes when I pointed this out). The service is 'Italian style' though: you will see the waiters chatting to each other a fair bit (in Italian of course), and it's sometimes a bit difficult to get their attention. Service expectations differ in Italy, and I think the service at Sartori (and in many other authentic Italian restaurants in London) reflects that.

UHQUOMeOpK9m_HeQNJSXjA.text: Large open windows and a glass facade welcome you into this cute little Italian bistro, where service was prompt and the mood bright and warm, despite the rain pouring outside.  As a group, we were set on pizza, and we were informed that were we to have our pie baked 'by the meter' we could have just a little bit more, as they would be square and conjoined by their ends as the slab cooks together in their massive oven.  We were inspired by this suggestion and gave the ol' thumbs up, and out they came with long wooden shelf with our pizza, merrily changing from one set of toppings to the next.  The ingredients were fresh, the sauce was rich, tomatoey and not at all too sweet, oily or watery and the crust had a good crisp yet bready lip to it that let you hold it nicely and encouraged you to finish it all off.   My only small complaint was that apparently one side of the oven is a little hotter than the other, so one crust edge caught a little too much heat and had a light sprinkling of brimstone taste to it.  I'll go back.. especially for the sausage and greens pizza.. it's rare to find nice open chunks of proper sausage and not just thin slices of cured salami like everywhere else.

vQrcfI5Zaj3Dh1ZKxbuQUw.text: The pizza is HUGE!! I and my friend order 1/2 meter of pizza for 2 people but we can't finish it. So I suggested you to go there as a group of 4 will be perfect. The taste is really good, I order parma ham pizza (can't remember Italian name). It seasoned with cheese, rocket leaves, and parma ham. Moreover, we ordered another plate of cabonara. Personally, I think it is quite ok. Lastly, the service of this restaurant is alright but I just worry about some staff impression. I asked for a ketchup but the staff responded quite aggressive to stop me ordering it. However, overall the food and atmosphere is good.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. 1/2 meter of 2 combination Pizza

yPTDnnVUovQF5fQd82KSYA.text: We went to Sartori while on a business trip in London based on the recommendation of a local bartender in a nearby pub in Piccadilly Circus. Because of the recommendation, we were able to get in to the busy restaurant with a time deadline (because of another reservation in one hour). It was a fortunate thing for us because the restaurant was of good quality and service.We had a group of 6 people, so we got lucky and the service to meet our expectations and their timing requirements was very good. The restaurant is a upscale Mediterranean version of Italian with thin crust pizzas and a variety of lighter options for dinner.Our group had a variety of dinner choices and everyone really enjoyed them. My pizza was very good, but I think was a bit light on toppings. The potion size was good though. But, the other dinner options were very good as told to me by my colleagues.I would recommend the restaurant based on the quality of the food and the service, despite the very busy nature of the place.

BqNWYm61e4AjU4QVXN0uxQ.text: On entering Sartori you hear the fabulously dramatic din of Italian staff and customers.  In fact, on the night we visited, most of the restaurant was filled with Italians - always a good sign at any Italian restaurant.  And it turns out that they were right.  The place serves ups some simple but very delicious dishes.  For starters, I had the smoked duck with rocket and avocado, it was very simple but just so so yummy.  The smoked duck was tender and full of flavour, and combined with the rocket, avocado, and sundried tomatoes, it was just so lovely and fresh.  For mains, it was the prawns & mussells linguine and again the dish was delicious.  The prawns firm and fresh, and the mussells not overcooked.  Sadly, we had no time to try the desserts but will definitely be back.  If you're expecting something exciting and different, then this is not for you but if you're just craving for some well cooked, simple Italian fare then it is well recommended.

TpjAxwpDbaJCsZ247sZ2ow.text: Great place for a little wine and pizza before or after theater in Covent Garden.  Pizza is properly Neopolitan with thin center,and puffy & chewy, blistered, outer crust.   Book ahead though (they're on Toptable) especially post-theater, the place is PACKED.

5xzE_cbB1bmeh9VvZbuKjw.text: Satori was started by the former team at Spaccanapoli.  The Crossrail project forced Spaccanapoli to move from Dean Street to its present location in Covent Garden.  Nothing has changed; even the restaurant looks pretty much the same, down to the exposed brick.  The food here is outstanding; although Sartori is known primarily for its pizza, everything is executed well.For starters, I would recommend the scamorza, breaded and served with some grilled vegetables.  I also enjoyed the panuozzi, which are basically two very thin slices of pizza dough filled with ham, cheese and rocket, amongst some other ingredients.  Terrific.  The eggplant is perfect as well.  The pizza is invariably good, thin, chewy doughy crust, high quality ingredients.  They serve pizza by the metre, so if you go in a large group you can mix and match ingredients.  My favorite is the bufalina.Finally, the pasta is terrific.  I've had the amatriciana and the carbonara; both are amongst the best i've had outside of Italy.Francesco (from Puglia) is the manager and a great guy.  You go a few times, and he remembers you.

RCpOsEFjnOVhyo62UaMItg.text: Great pizza! We were a large group so split a meter of pizza and got to try all different ones. Had a slice of the vegetarian, the Toscana and the Rucola and all were delicious. Plenty of toppings on a thin crust. Also had a selection of starters including a cheesy aubergine dish which was nice. Topped the meal off with a dessert of  creamy pannacotta, mmm. All in all, a nice find.

H4w2byyE3VqU9WDXgDdh1Q.text: We went to Sartori for a quick pre-theatre meal and it was AMAZING. Great Service  very friendly staff. I took the gnocchi with tomato sauce which was just perfect . Thumbs up :)

OVE7vs61GKvmGodgr8bXqA.text: Last week I had the chance to taste the pasta carbonara here and I was stunned. My pasta was more than delicious, it was heavenly delicious. It was perfect. I think I am addict now, a pasta addict.

HbUoWjdb7GZA68uEdcpV8Q.text: As I walked past Sartori i saw a perfectly blistered pizza crust on the pie being eaten at the window table.  thinking it had to be wood-fired, I walked in and could just smell a hint of wood smoke.  I ordered some apps, a pie and a bottle of wine.  All were superb and the portions were perfect.  I met the owner, Francesco and he gave me a tour of his wood fired pizza oven that he imported from Naples.  This is the best pizza in London and may be some of the best overall food i have eaton in London in quite some time.  if you love great food and friendly, prompt service, this is the place to go.

mXoFsDByUfG78fSqZW0uKA.text: We went to Sartori for a quick pre-theatre meal and it was perfect. Big portions cooked quickly and the service was friendly and speedy too. I had pasta with smoked mozzarella and aubergine  yum  and my companions had the gnocchi with tomato sauce which was also tasty. Wine selection could be improved upon  there are only two or three reds you can get by the glass and they're not too exciting. Overall though, a good and reliable place to have dinner before or after a show (it's right by Leicester Square theatre so ideally located for many of the theatres). I'd certainly return.

C_H9BVv29GyBf5-iSpnNmA.text: We ate here very late after a show (and I mean that we were the last customers that they served at 11pm). Ordered their Antipasto Misto, a bottle Montepulciano and Calzonpizza (not quite a Calzone). They were all quite excellent, fresh, tasty and served with the biggest smiles, despite the late hour. The decor is quite starkly chic and it is a little crowded, but for atmosphere and taste, you'll struggle to get more authentic Italian while in the UK. We ate downstairs near the amazing oven and the whole thing was a great, if too short, experience. The prices are too low It is so good to get genuine Italian from genuine Italians!! As M Smith says in the first review: its a big Goodbye to the pizza chains  try this place if you want real!

x0OqgUn-_oMzK1MozB-Nxg.text: The pizza here is great.  Proper neopolitan style, thin crispy base, nice puffy chewy crust, with high quality toppings.  I've tried the bufalina, margherita, a pizza with a few types of cheeses and ham, and one with different veggies.  I was not expecting to like the veggie one because I normally think mixing veggies (especially zucchini) and pizza is a crime, but this one was so good I stole a whole slice from my friend.  I haven't tried the pasta but it looks very appetizing. In fact, when the gentleman at the table next to me left some spagetti carbonara after paying his bill, it was hard to resist the urge to try a bite.  The only disappointing item I've had here was the vegetable soup which was too salty and kind of gross.

pvli75gACVxWmWVtR7n0OA.text: Frequented by our office on a regular basis, this restaurant offers up all great things Italian. A great variety on their lunch time set menu for £10.95 (2 courses) you never leave hungry...it's usually hard to finish the plate. Staff are really friendly and always make you feel welcome. Great venue for large parties as they have a big downstairs area. Must tries are their fresh grilled mixed vegetables with balsamic vinegar, Aubergine and mozzarella baked with tomato, Parmesan and basil, pasta carbonara and orecchiette pasta with broccoli, sausages and Parmesan. The pizzas have also got to be tried, authentic thin base with lots of topping.

r1Ee6-EAi8PDrI8E3Lsw7w.text: One of the best Italian restaurants I have visited so far. My husband and I had pasta which was delicious. We chose to have recommendation for wine as we were confused which one would go best with white sauce and sea-food pasta. The recommendations were indeed helpful (10 on 10) and made us enjoy our food a lot more!!! Would love to come back with friends again. :)

JHU0dqi0mj1Ui90Mxq5K8Q.text: Visited this place thinking it might be ok. We were. Blown away. The best Italian food we've ever had, anywhere.My gnocchi was perfectly cooked, and the sauce was amazing. My wife had penne diavolo, and it was al dente. And when I say it was al dente, I mean it was *actually* al dente. Perfectly executed.The service was prompt, and the Italian gentlemen running the place gave us a preview of our visit to Italy the following week.We will pass back through London on our way back to the U.S. in a few days and we're seriously considering eating here again even though it'll be out of the way. Eat here.

3kDByicPQivLYmwkVvf0og.text: Sartori near Leicester Square is a pretty basic Italian restaurant with everything on the menu you would expect, like pizza, pasta etc. Me and my party all had pizza and everybody enjoyed their food but it was nothing special. The service wasn't very good, but not a disaster either - just meh. So you know very basic, nothing special, but ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Pizza with mozzarella, anchovies, capers and olives.

hnu31px4dd4PEWfK3FN3eg.text: Walked in randomly, and the Italian restaurant is not only busy, but also full of Italians, great and promising start. We went for smoked duck, sundried tomatoes, avocado and balsamic vinegar as a shared starter. This was on the specials menu, well worth a look at. For main I opted for the ruccola pizza and dared not ask for different toppings as per instructions on the menu, but instead put my trust into the pizzaiolos, but I feel customizing your pizza to your make it your own, is also part of the experience... Having said that, this is a must place to have a pizza, next time I will try one of their pastas, as their ingredients were fresh and well prepared. I wasn't that much more adventurous than a house red, but just one glass was enough for me. Very filling and a must go for good pizza. I will also try and open up that second stomach for some dolci/dessert, maybe learn a bit of Italian so I can order in Italian like some of the diners.. or is that a bit much? ! I feel the food was very good but fell short of 'wow' - will definitely be back to tackle my fave secondi, pollo milanese !

P6dkg7MqmIP86qTi8DKGFg.text: Had lunch here today with the family. Service was excellent. We shared two pizzas that were average. Maybe it was just us, but both seemed to need more seasoning. I would try here again, but I would order something different (we had the Rustica and Americano). They had a lot of other pizza and Italian choices

wlMQ7IYYt4MQfis3uQFK2g.text: Ok pizza combined with bad service. I really didn't expect it to be like this and I'm disappointed, but maybe it's because of the area - they don't feel the need to try hard.We went for lunch on a Saturday. It's two floors - ground and basement. The basement accommodates larger reservations. Maybe half the tables were occupied when we were there.We ordered two of the most standard pizzas possible - the margherita and the classic marinara. I say "classic" because they have a pizza called "marinara" on their menu, which has nothing to do with an actual marinara. It has anchovies and capers and a pizza like that is generally called a napoletana, but that name was already taken by another pizza. Anyway, after explaining to them what a classic marinara was, they finally made it, although only after arguing with me that it shouldn't have basil on it (and charged me 75p for the addition of this).So when the pizzas came there were several things wrong with both. The margherita, which we ordered without olive oil, had olive oil poured on top. They tried to tell us it didn't have any, but then later admitted it did. The marinara didn't have any garlic and when we inquired about it, they said they decided not to put it on because it was roasted in oil and we asked for no oil. Fine, but tell me that, ask what I'd like to do, and the obvious solution is to put fresh garlic anyway. They ended up brining me a plate of raw chopped garlic - as if that's the same as actually having it cooked on a pizza. What am I supposed to do with that? Eat a bite of pizza and then a bite of raw garlic? The marinara also had very little tomato sauce - it was dry and cracking. They brought some extra on the side, but it wasn't pizza sauce, it was just a vat of pasta sauce.On top of that, we asked a waiter two separate times whether he could please take a picture for us. The first time he just looked at us and walked away and the second time he said "give me a minute" and never came back. On purpose. Rude waiters, lousy service, amateur pizza.Nothing was right about this place. No apologies for any of the mistakes. I would not ever go back.

-wfeEbGvHP56Auc7YQPKiw.text: There is nothing worse than a poor attitude. There is simply no need for it, nor is there any excusing it. Especially if you work in hospitality! Note that I am asking not asking for all smiles all the time, but if a customer (operative word being customer) tells you that they are not happy with something, sighing, huffing and puffing is not acceptable.I ordered the octopus with rocket to start, followed by the sea bass. When my starter arrived it was covered in parsley. Now, I hate parsley, but I didn't complain as I just assumed that I had missed that on the menu. I remember seeing that parsley was in some of the main dishes, so I specifically took extra care to order a main that didn't have any.Low and behold when my main arrived, I'll give you one guess as to what was used as the garnish? Yep, you guessed it, that evil tasting green herb. I can hear you asking, '"why didn't you just put it to one side?" Reason being, because it was chopped into sand size particles and it wasn't just around the edge of the bowl, but it had infected the tomato sauce too!I informed the waiter of my dislike (hate) for the green goblin and he said something along the lines of 'just eat around it.' "I will not just it around it!" I thought to myself Would you ask Superman to just skirt around a pile of kryptonite? I think not! Why I had to explain myself further I don't know, but still, I was made to justify myself so I went on to explain that I had not complained about the 'evil' in my starter, but I was unwilling to endure it for a second time. This is where the huffing and puffing started and with the roll of his eyes he took the plate away.Honestly the dish wasn't that great anyway but perhaps I just ordered the wrong things. My three other companions has a lovely meal. Overall I'd have probably given the food 3 stars but for making me feel bad, you only get two.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Seabass

uEIGcqcfFn4Mx0DzTP8cpA.text: Very nice and very Italian restaurant. The choice of pizza they have is astonishing. Also, the staff is very professional, making your choice of food very easy with useful advice. Also, despite the fact that the restaurant is not big, there's no problem coming in with a child in a buggy (we made a reservation beforehand of course).

VsEYTmS9EcLpmOK5ELPqPw.text: Brilliant- authentic Italian food, efficient service, reasonably priced (particularly for the quality!). Would highly recommend and would go back.

_bYOgqfrd3JS861GDpgQKg.text: Had the parpardelle with mushrooms, courgette, and cream. It was delicious but on the heavy side. My friend ordered a pizza and we shared the bruschetta. All in all, a fantastic meal. Their pizza seems to be the most popular item, and the crust is delicious.My biggest complaint is just that they completely forgot my dish, so we had to wait an extra long time for them to put in the order after the rest of the food had already come out. Also, service is completely slow. The staff are more than friendly! But even with just a few tables (and what seemed like more servers than tables....),  we just couldn't get their attention!

C7hra0dljJ0ucp8aWJ-oYA.text: We unassumingly walked in to this restaurant as we were standing directly in front of it and my friend decided he wanted pizza.  I was petrified to walk into an unknown restaurant in Leicester Square and didn't even have time to check my Yelp app before my friend had dragged me in.  Charming Italian waiters greeted us so I started to relax a bit.As I perused the menu the food and the font seemed all too familiar and my question was answered that this is indeed the sister restaurant of Santore in Exmouth Market.  I was immediately put at ease.A decent bottle of Sangiovese, some bubbly0crusted pizza with very tasty sausage and greens and I was good to go (not to mention some nice attention from the waiters).  A good place to eat in an area lacking in options.

j5RfDKrNYm5-E5SObMsFbA.text: I was surprised. I thought: Italian? Near Leicester Square? It's going to be (a) not run by actual Italians and (b) low food quality. Quite the contrary.My friend and I shared their neapolitan antipasto, a lot of the food in it was good and some of it delicious. Then came the pizza (by the meter) and it was damn tasty! Both the dough and the toppings. They know their neapolitan pizza-making here.

2_SLSEzkjX5Bw6dsxbLGNA.text: This was such a delicious spot for pre-theatre dinner! Though it's listed as a pizza place, we all had the pasta and were not disappointed. It was honestly one of the best restaurant carbonaras I have ever had - praise which does not come lightly! The staff was very friendly and the wine menu extensive, with several affordable options. The set menu is a great way to go - less than 11£ and there is an appetizer and main plate. It is worth getting in before the rush though - the restaurant was full 20 minutes after we sat down!

DnR49cTd3QctPuLvGusOiw.text: Ideal location for dinner before theatre. Very busy but managed to get us a table for two on turning up without a reservation. Quick and tasty pasta. Worth a visit

wAVzQxx30EMgU0nGCX6wBQ.text: Went here with a large group of about 16 people and I have to say, given the glowing Yelp reviews I expected something akin to the glorious Italian food I shovelled into my mouth while touring around the Northern and Tuscan regions of Italy last summer. However, I was more than a little dismayed. First: the service. Clearly everyone here is Italian, which is usually a great omen of deliciousness to come. But this time it led to a miscommunication. Our friend ordered a seafood mix with pasta and when the food arrived he was presented with a slab of swordfish. When my friend protested, the waiter began arguing with him and gesticulating at the menu at the thing he allegedly said he wanted. A few of us testified to hearing him say the other dish, but the waiter refused to acknowledge us in his mini-rampage, assuring him directly that that was indeed what he ordered. Our friend was too embarrassed at this point to continue the argument which was heating up and relented. To their credit, he did say the swordfish was well done and tasty. But I would have fought to the death. The guy sitting next to me ordered a creamy mushroomy, pancetta with spaghetti. I heard him say the pasta part, 100%. They returned with his food, almost 45 minutes later, and there were chunked potatoes on the side rather than the tossed pasta he has asked for. The waitress did get them to make the pasta, but it was placed on the side for him to mix in rather than creating a cohesive, completed dish.My friend and I each got a wood-fire baked, Naples-inspired, 'I Panuozzi'. Mine was the Sarracino with sausage, aubergines, and mozzarella. His was the Estate with Parma Ham, tomatoes, and mozzarella. We went halfsies. These covered, filled, pizza parcels sounded incredible but I found them to be slightly burnt, under-filled, and hard, perhaps due to the delay in stove-to-table delivery. Either way, I just wasn't satisfied. Perhaps I should have just stuck with traditional pizza, which is what this restaurant was recommended to me for. Also, it was SO noisy downstairs. Just unnecessarily so due to the crowding of 4 large tables in the same room as the oven. This made it unbearably hot and almost impossible to speak to anyone. Don't get me wrong- I don't mind the occasional 'Happy Birthday' medley. Just a bit disappointing as this was meant to be our 'social' event. There was lots of clanging and metal dropping which added to the cloud of buzzing conversation. Came out with a headache.

fg0pmajZNLmhYtYr4miVIA.text: Delicious Italian food, but I went with a large party on a Friday night and we had a somewhat disastrous experience with the service. There was clearly a language barrier which wouldn't have been a red flag for me had the waiters not been disdainful and accusatory toward my friend when an order clearly got lost in translation. Similarly, they poured drinks and handed out menus when we were trying to get them not to and they seemed irritated about our requests in general. The downstairs was much too noisy for easy conversation - not just from the chatter of other tables in such a cavernous space but from all the crashes of dishes and carts among the serving staff. I'm not sure why the reviews are so high here except that the food was good, but surely London has places with good eats and service.

PiFE-x9aEyfVnrTjoUlhEg.text: I recently joined a school dinner club which has given me the opportunity to get out and try some new places win classmates I might normally not spent time with. It's a lovely idea, even if it does just add to my yelp to-do list. Sartori was the choice for January, and I was excited to see if I could find a place that served as good of pizza as I had recently had in Italy. Their menu promised authentic Neapolitan style pizza, and I was eager to try. Unfortunately, what I ordered, or maybe my poor understanding of the layout of the menu lead to, what turned up being not even close to what I expected. It was good, flavorful and fresh, but you know, it's always a bummer when you're excited about one thing and you get something else. Like getting a sweater on Christmas in 1996 when you asked for a furby. The service was alright, not very present and difficult to flag down. Unfortunate that my expectations of good service have changed so much since moving to London. The location is great, of course, just in the heart o the West End. Overall, it was an okay meal. Certainly nice enough, but no candle to Italy, and nothing to yelp home about.

VX9dmwkeJlxKukgV3ggNeQ.text: One great italian restaurant in the middle of the theatre district. one would expect twice the price for the food in this restaurant.The food is great and the waiters are authentic italian (communicating with each other throughout the restaurant. Frankly, that can be a bit loud, nevertheless it really gives you this special italian flair :) )

dgFyK_aAbaF7ad_9w1bQ5A.text: Great authentic Italian restaurant. I went with Italian friends and they loved it - that says a lot! Also a ton of other customers were Italian. I had the swordfish which I loved. My friends got delicious pizza with crusty and airy dough. Would definitely recommend for good Italian food.

ZFEg36ZaHq-N5-Jzi7o0aA.text: Amazing pizza, I had the cured ham one + great wine and ambience...absolutely worth it !!

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

W4G7SLkHUQnHO-86fQHyog.text: Wow! Delicious authentic Italian food right in the heart of London. The pizza, the pasta, the appetizers, all sublime! One thing to be aware of is that this place is really busy. A reservation is definitely recommended. I got lucky and came early right before the rush of dinner service to grab a table.I got the linguini gamberoni & cozze (linguini with prawns and mussels). It was absolutely delicious! An awesome seafood pasta that had really fresh prawns and mussels. We also ordered some white wine and calamari as an appetizer. Everything was well done and tasted awesome!It can be quite loud inside and the seating is tight, but I think it's worth it to stop by this authentic place. The waiters are knowledgeable and if you don't know what each thing is, just ask or look it up on google.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Linguini with prawns and mussels
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

LffF3k2Hpi5VxmH0mOnopg.text: All I can say is there are a number of Italian restaurants around the same area, but I'm not disappointed at all for the choice we made. With a friendly group of employees and quite the extent of a menu, I enjoyed my whole experience. From the grilled vegetables, and garlic pizza bread to start, to my Calzone,I enjoyed it all. I would love to come back again to try their other dishes but I will be leaving soon. So I will leave it up to you to decide.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Calzone
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Wood fire pizza
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Grilled Vegatables

C5xA8c7F3kZUCrHIyWnbNQ.text: 5 friends, 4 dishes, 1 bottle of wine, priceless time together. Would recommend to a friend but not a MUST visit. The Italian food hits the spot. The spaghetti sauce over indexed on deliciousness. Grab a margarita pizza as an appetizer. Say by the door so it was chilly but they let us slip in on a Friday night, so we appreciate it. Busy staff, good vibes inside.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

asKXQY8W9NlowxpltEwZpQ.text: Amazing homemade spaghetti and lasagna!! Ordered on Uber Eats and was amazed at the flavor and appearance considering it was delivered on a motorbike. I would recommend this place to anyone traveling to London!!

IxW_nMldrp6EF7VTPelhRw.text: My husband and I came in after looking at several Yelp reviews and you Yelpers didn't disappoint. We were seated almost immediately without a reservation and the seafood pasta dishes the my husband and I ate were fantastic. I will definitely come back the next time I'm in London.

j1BN2AarSP1mAeWj3fgDnA.text: I went here some time ago for a friends birthday gathering so apologies if I don't remember exact details, but what I DO remember, was that the food was tasty and well priced considering the location!! I think the most important part here is ONE METER LONG PIZZA. Which is crazy??? But also amazing. At the end of the day it's average but tasty italian food for a good price. But if you want to impress a large group of friends who are just expecting average food, bringing them here and ordering the meter long pizza is not a bad idea.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Selfies are important for meter long pizzas.

vKL8Wnlo-fEV4J48H4PYrQ.text: This was not the best Italian I've had, in fact the poorest meal I've had, the atmosphere is nice however, reading from the other reviews maybe the chef was having a bad day today, but the garlic bread was so dry, my friends bruschetta was over loaded with olive oil and tomatoes in addition to that my carbonara had lots of oil and fatty meat, I did not enjoy it here :(

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

sI18aoaPjXW3VSjxRWjyHA.text: Went here with a small group of friends (one of them being Italian and had previously visited several times).  Have to say I was very impressed with the food.We had the Scamorza (smoked mozzarella in breadcrumbs) and Involtini (aubergine and mozzarella in sauce) for appetizers.  They were amazing! I could have easily had 2 of these and been fully satisfied.For mains I had the ear pasta with broccoli and Italian Sausage.  It was different to what I normally eat for pasta and really enjoyed it.  Filly and flavorful and didn't feel too indulgent. Others had the gnocchi in tomatto sauce and mozzarella.  Also amazing but an insane amount of cheese, so make sure you're hungry as this one's very filling.  The Bolognese also was amazing and came with equally impressive Pappardelle noodles.The service was friendly and down to earth.  Very welcoming, although a few staff aside from our waiter were a bit frazzled and couldn't be bothered with our inquiries.  No big hit however.  Also we had reservations on a Saturday at 7:30.  When we arrived they were nearly full but a few open tables here and there.  By the time we left the queue was massive! Not sure if these were all walk-ins or reservations that had backed up, but word to the wise make a reservation if you're coming on a weekend night.Overall this was a very impressive Italian style joint and I'm eager to come back to try some of the non-pasta mains or even their impressive pizza offerings (which include pizzas up to a Meter long!!).

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

EO8bnH_V6VKZBsy9-4MHEw.text: I've passed by this restaurant several times on my way to Chinatown and I"ve always dismissed it thinking it's one of those touristy Italian restaurants like L'ulivo in Leicester sq.  I was meeting a group of friends for dinner one night as they heard it was quite good.  Sartori has one of those menus where they have almost too many selections which made it really difficult to decide what to get.  I was so set on getting pizza because it looks so good but decided to get the homemade pasta with seafood.  It was really good - good amount of fresh seafood.  I tried a bite of the tuna pizza (no cheese!) which was also really good.Definitely would consider going back to try some of the other dishes!

Pf5iSRF_BDc7bbl10WbTuA.text: Nice food, but terrible service. We decided to pay for our meal, which came to over £150 minus the optional service charge as some of the food brought to the table was wrong. The waiter then pulled my friend aside and told us we had not paid enough, she was so embarrassed that she quickly paid the service charge, but I thought this was unacceptable.

HKDTYyTm_Hat_mnFrUyozQ.text: Absolutely blown away by the incredible flavors of the wood-fire oven baked pizza!Walking around like a typical tourist decided to grab lunch somewhere near Leister Square, this place is slightly hidden from the main touristy area (thank god) with 4 of us we decided to split the 3/4 meter pizza which was the perfect size as we were starving! The place feels classy with the business lunches going on around us and the wide variety of wines looked very tempting for a tasting at noon.The pizza itself was def insta/snapchat worthy as it spanned across 2 tables, whoever came up with that idea is a genius I tell ya! The flavors, service and company def made it worth the hour long trek into Central London and that day was def one of the highlights of our trip!

FguS6bPRbU8Zy9A4otDFog.text: The service was meh, the pizza was average but the pasta was amazing! Definitely good and bad things about this place but good for a one time try.

Q5yDyWibdwS3cpwUF3lX7Q.text: Was here to have a nice Italian - saw 4 stars on yelp and gave this a try. My pasta was decent but pizza was not nice at all.

EV7wmo_moMLR4Z0UpyJ-uA.text: The range of pizza options is more than enough to satisfy everyone and you can order a few different options of pizza toppings if you do order the pizza by the meter so it is near impossible to not please the entire crowd. I do not know what toppings I ended up trying as I think we ordered almost every one across the numerous meters of pizza that the group ordered. Even stuffed to the brim with all the pizza I found some room to split a desert with a fellow diner and it was not a mistake!The atmosphere of the restaurant was inviting and while crowded made for a great night out with friends both new and old. And the tables are well set up for the long slabs of pizza, with plenty of room for plates and drinks with the pizzas occupying the elevated center spot on the table.Overall I highly recommend this place and with it's central location it makes for a great meal out in London whether as the highlight of the night or as a pre-show meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. Pizza by the metre.
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom. dessert.
Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

bL8TdkLr2tm36CW4eYS97g.text: I tend to refuse to eat Italian food outside of Italy - I know Im a snob! Eitherway, didnt really want to go there, but restaurant was picked by Italian friend for long over due catch up. No regrets! Definitely recommend this restaurant as on eof the best Italians outside of Italy ive been to! Full all night, full of italians as well! Thats gotta be a good sign right? Consideing location as well this is a real hidden gem!

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

Jof8qcHRNxtYQTz7zmwckQ.text: Amazing pasta! Stopped in quick for some ravioli and garlic bread and it was quick and delicious.

fJZggxmrZiqpdS0RkAGPNw.text: The best pasta and sauce I've had possibly ever besides my Italian Mom's who is an awesome cook.

photos.caption: Photo of Sartori Restaurant - London, United Kingdom

6Tsv8xe6ak4QxWEQYkDpqg.text: My first dinner in London was at Sartori and I'm not sure we could have made a better choice! My only qualm is the physical space; you are literally almost elbow-to-elbow with the table next to you, which felt a little claustrophobic for me at times. Besides that, everything was awesome. All our servers seemed to speak fluent Italian and were very nice, even though we were clearly tourists and had no idea what we were doing. Calamari was just okay, but our pastas and desserts were absolutely delicious.

YyDsOc8bpFLeWYQw5w7Utg.text: Great Pizza and Pasta!! You better make a reservation because it's really busy
